Gibbs free energy of Cu@HZ40 corresponding to FFA adsorption (Ori), C-O cleavage (TS-1), Hydrogenation of intermediate products (TS-2) and PDO desorption (TS-3). The energy profiles in the red line and the pink line were based on the C2-O and C5-O bond cleavage modes of the FFA ring opening, respectively. Bifunctional metal-acid catalysts have been widely used in the process of upgrading the molecules of biomass. As an important bifunctional catalyst, metal @ zeolite exhibits excellent sintering resistance and efficient catalytic performance, which is significant for improving practical applications. While the development of Al-rich zeolite-confined nanocluster catalysts is still a considerable challenge. In this paper, Cu@ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40) catalyst with Al-rich ZSM-5 zeolite-confined copper nanoclusters were designed and synthesized by the in-situ ligand-assisted hydrothermal crystallization method. The average size of the encapsulation metal clusters was only 2.3 nm after treatment at 400°C for 2 h in a hydrogen environment, which exhibits excellent thermal stability. 27Al MAS NMR and Pyridine-adsorbed IR (Py-IR) spectra confirmed that Al was successfully introduced into the zeolite framework. The intimate metal- Brønsted acidic site distribution enables complete conversion of furfuryl alcohol and 92.1 % selectivity of pentanediols. DFT calculations revealed that the high catalytic activity in catalyzing the ring opening of furfuryl alcohol to pentanediols could be attributed to the unique electronic effect in the Al-rich catalyst Cu@ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40). The in-situ ligand-assisted hydrothermal crystallization method will be very attractive regarding the simplicity required for industrial production. The Al-rich Cu@ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40) catalyst was endowed with rich and dense metal-Brønsted acidic sites by a simple in-situ synthesis method, providing a practical and feasible path for the high-value utilization of biomass molecules. Graphical abstract Al-rich Cu@MFI catalyst encapsulating copper nanoparticles exhibits significant pentanediols selectivity and high anti-sintering performance in boosting furfuryl alcohol upgrading to pentanediols. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pentanediols Encapsulation Cu nanoparticles Furfuryl alcohol Metal-Acid Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Metal nanoparticles (NPS) have essential applications in heterogeneous catalysis due to their high activity [1]. At the same time, metal nanoparticles are unstable in actual catalytic reactions due to their small size and high surface energy, which can easily lead to metal agglomeration [2]. Metal encapsulation strategies have been increasingly investigated in catalytic reactions to overcome the problem of the sintering of metal nanoparticles [3,4]. Zeolites have been extensively studied as encapsulation supports for metal NPS such as Cu [5,6], Ru [7,8], Pd [9,10], and Pt [11]. The metal encapsulation strategies confine the metal particles within zeolite pores or cages and inhibit migration and sintering of metal particles, achieving nanocrystallisation and homogenization of metal species. In addition, the confined environment also has unique effects and significant advantages in improving selectivity and activity [12]. Impregnation and ion exchange are the traditional metal encapsulation strategies for zeolites. However, the impregnation method is limited by the pore size and accessible surface area of the zeolite, which cannot effectively achieve metal encapsulation. It puts forward higher requirements on metal precursors. Ion exchange utilizes charge balance on Si-OH-Al to achieve metal encapsulation, which has the disadvantage of limited metal loading and a significant impact on the acidic properties of the catalyst, especially for reactions that require the participation of acidic functions [13]. The in-situ hydrothermal synthesis avoids the above drawbacks and has attracted the interest of researchers. In previous reports, the in-situ hydrothermal synthesis methods have mainly focused on the synthesis of all silica zeolite-confined metal NPS, such as Pd@Silicalite-1 [14,15], Ni@Silicalite-1 [16] and Rh@Silicalite-1 [17]. However, there are few reports on the in-situ hydrothermal synthesis of confined metal-acid bifunctional catalysts. The activation of C-O and C-C bonds is generally involved in biomass upgrading, which often requires the synergistic effect of metal and acidic sites [18–21]. Furfuryl alcohol (FFA) is a critical biomass platform molecule. The ring-opening of FFA to produce pentanediols (PDO) (Scheme 1 ) can compensate for the lack of petroleum-based pentadiene feedstock [22,23]. This progress has been demonstrated to be a tandem reaction catalyzed by metal-acid bifunctional catalysis [24,25]. Firstly, Furfuryl alcohol is adsorbed onto the catalyst, breaking the C-O in the furan ring under the action of the Brønsted (B) acidic site to form a diene intermediate. The intermediate is then selectively hydrogenated under the action of the activated hydrogen on the metal site to produce the pentanediol. As an essential solid acid, the acidity of the Al-containing zeolite is mainly from the tetra-coordinated Al structure [26]. It has the advantage of being acid-tunable and is widely used in the design of metal-acid bifunctional catalysts. At present, the realization of Al-rich zeolite confined metal clusters faces many challenges. For example, the presence of metal salts leads to the failure of the assembly of zeolite units, which quickly leads to the formation of many non-tetra-coordinated Al species [13]. These problems limit the application scenarios of bifunctional metal@zeolite catalysts. Therefore, the successful synthesis of metal-acid bifunctional metal@zeolite catalysts is of great significance for improving their practical applications. Previous research results have confirmed that Cu and the B acidic sites of zeolite can synergistically catalyze the production of PDO from FFA [27,28]. Here, we developed an Al-rich catalyst Cu@HZ40 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40) by the in-situ hydrothermal crystallization method, which achieved a highly selective ring opening of furfuryl alcohol to produce pentanediol. 27Al MAS NMR confirmed that Al has intercalated into the zeolite framework as tetracoordination Al. Py-IR spectra and NH3-TPD analyses showed that the catalyst possesses abounds of B acid. After reduction treatment at 400 °C in a hydrogen atmosphere for 2 h, the small-sized copper nanoclusters showed high sintering resistance. The activity evaluation results showed that the selectivity of Cu@HZ40 to pentanediol was much higher than that of the catalyst Cu/HZ40 prepared by the impregnation method. DFT calculations further confirmed that the excellent catalytic activity in the ring opening of FFA to PDO could be attributed to the unique electronic effect of Cu@HZ40. This particular preparation method enables the metal to be encapsulated in the Al-rich zeolite, effectively exploiting the synergistic effect of acid-metal sites and exhibiting efficient catalytic properties. The special structure realizes the proximity of metal and acid sites, inhibits the agglomeration of copper nanoclusters in the reaction process, and shows friendliness to practical applications. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthetic strategy for Cu@HZ40 catalyst The synthesis of MFI zeolites is generally carried out at high temperatures (> 150°C) and alkaline conditions, which poses a challenge to the stability of metal precursors. In this paper, an in situ hydrothermal method assisted by tetraethylenepentamine (TEPA) ligands was adopted to prevent the precipitation of copper precursors during the synthesis process. The synthesis process is shown in Scheme 2 . The interaction between the TEPA ligand and Cu ions is more potent than that between Cu ions and OH ions. Thus, Cu ions are preferentially complex with TEPA, avoiding the precipitation of metal in the form of colloidal hydroxide and leading to the heterogeneous distribution of Cu in MFI. Cu-TEPA binds to the zeolite framework through electrostatic and van der Waals interactions, ensuring uniform distribution and encapsulation of metals in the zeolite. In the process of encapsulation of Cu metal by Al-rich zeolite, the organic structure directing agent will interact with the metal precursor, hindering the construction of the primary zeolite unit. Here, MFI crystal seeds were introduced to direct the construction of primary zeolite units. The synthesis of Cu@HZ40 samples was achieved without introducing sodium ions and avoiding the tedious steps of subsequent ion exchange. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts As shown in Fig 1 a, all samples present the typical structure of MFI. XRF data in Table 1 showed that the Cu content in Cu/HZ40 and Cu@HZ40 was similar, and the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio was close to the theoretical value. These results indicate that the MFI-type zeolite catalyst was successfully synthesized by the in-situ hydrothermal method. The diffraction peaks attributed to CuO in all samples were not observed at 35.5° and 38.7°, indicating that the Cu species present a small particle morphology after calcination. The Cu/HZ40 sample prepared by the impregnation method has an apparently saturated adsorption platform in the low relative pressure region and the absence of a hysteresis loop in the high P/P0 region (Fig 1b). This indicates that Cu/HZ40 was mainly a microporous structure [29]. While the low relative pressure region of the Cu@HZ40 sample shows similar adsorption isotherms to Cu/HZ40, indicating the existence of micropores in Cu@HZ40. In addition, the hysteresis loop and pore size distribution observed in Cu@HZ40 indicate the presence of a hierarchical pore structure. The formation of hierarchical pore structure is probably caused by introducing TEPA, which can promote the diffusion of raw materials and products in the catalytic reaction [30–32]. The micropore area of Cu@HZ40 was only 98.0 m2 / g, which is far lower than that of Cu/HZ40. It may be that the introduction of Cu nanoparticles into the channel and pores reduce the micropore area. While the surface area > 200 m2 / g and the hierarchical pore structure provide sufficient effective active sites for the catalytic reaction. FT-IR was used to record the surface groups of the catalyst. It was found that the presence of characteristic bands at 452 cm−1,798 cm−1, and 1102 cm−1, corresponding to the Si-O vibration peak in the SiO4 unit, and the feature signals at 548 cm−1 and 1226 cm−1 were the characteristic bands of the MFI topological structure [6]. These results showed that the MFI-structured catalyst was successfully synthesized by the in-situ hydrothermal method. The 27Al MAS NMR spectrum of Cu/HZ40 shows a strong resonance centered at 54.1 ppm, attributed to tetracoordinated Al. A primary resonance centered at 54.1 ppm and a weak resonance around 0 ppm corresponding to octahedral-Al were observed in the 27Al MAS NMR spectrum of Cu@HZ40 [7,11], implying that most of the Al atoms were inserted into the zeolite framework. The introduction of Cu did not affect the formation of tetracoordinated Al. HRTEM and EDS-mapping were used to further study the structural morphology of Cu NPS and the distribution of Al in Cu/HZ40-400 R and Cu@HZ40-400 R samples. Fig. 2 a displays that the surface of Cu/HZ40-400R was distributed with Cu NPS in the range of 2-14 nm with an average surface particle size of 7.1 nm. And there were many large particles of Cu species present in the catalyst. Fig. 2b shows Cu NPS with narrow particle size distribution (1-3 nm) and an average pore size of only 2.3 nm. EDX-mapping analysis showed that uniform Cu NPS (Fig. 2d and e) and Al were uniformly distributed in Cu @ HZ40-400R (Fig. 2g), which proved that the in-situ prepared Cu@HZ40-400R maintained smaller Cu NPS and more uniform distribution than the Cu/HZ40-400R prepared by the impregnation method. Due to the low Tamman temperature of copper, Cu NPS is prone to agglomeration in the hydrogen atmosphere during the reaction and reduction process, resulting in reduced utilization efficiency of active sites [33–35]. To further explore the anti-sintering performance of the confined Cu NPS of Cu@HZ40. All samples were treated in the hydrogen atmosphere at different temperature conditions. The results are shown in Fig 3 . For the Cu/HZ40 sample (Fig. 3c and d), a new diffraction peak appeared at 43.3o after treatment in the hydrogen atmosphere at 300°C, corresponding to Cu (111) (JCPDS 04–0836). As the treating temperature increases, the half-width of the diffraction peak at 43.3o decreases, and the peak intensity increases, indicating that the size of the metallic Cu NPS gradually increases and sintering agglomeration. However, the confined Cu@HZ40 sample (Fig. 3a and b) has no Cu (111) diffraction peak that appeared at 43.3 after 400° treatment in a hydrogen atmosphere. Even after 600 °C hydrogen treatment, it still shows excellent sintering resistance. These results indicate that the Cu@HZ40 sample synthesized by the in-situ hydrothermal method exhibits a superior anti-sintering performance due to the unique confinement effect of the zeolite channels or cages on Cu NPS, which inhibits Cu NPS migration and agglomeration in the high-temperature hydrogen atmosphere. XPS was used to characterize the samples after calcination and reduction to explore the surface metal valence of the samples. The results are shown in Fig. 4 a and b. The Cu 2p signal was observed around 943 eV corresponding to the Cu satellite in Cu/HZ40 and Cu@HZ40 samples, which means that the valence state of the sample after calcination mainly exists in the form of Cu2+ [36]. Following reduction, the satellite peak of Cu/HZ40-400R disappeared, indicating that Cu2 + was reduced to Cu +/Cu0. While the satellite peak still existed in the Cu@HZ40-400R, and the Cu 2p 3/2 signals presented two overlapping peaks at 936.1 eV and 933.3 eV, ascribed to Cu2+ and Cu+/Cu0, respectively [37]. Compared to the Cu/HZ40-400R catalyst prepared by the impregnation method, a slight positive shift of 0.4 eV was found in Cu@HZ40-400R. This might indicate that Cu NPS has more positive charges after confinement as the result of electron induction between the Cu NPS and the zeolite framework [6,7]. The reducibility of Cu species in the catalyst was investigated by H2-TPR, and the profiles are displayed in Fig. 5 a. A reduction peak at 240°C was observed for Cu/HZ40, corresponding to the reduction of uniformly distribution CuO to Cu0 particles. Cu@HZ40 shows a low-temperature reduction peak at 198°C, attributed to the small Cu species particles reduce to Cu+ / Cu0 species on the external surface of ZSM-5. Differently, a higher reduction peak appeared at 447°C was shown with Cu@HZ40, attributed to the highly dispersed Cu nanoparticle species inside the zeolite to Cu0 species [38,39]. This was probably caused by the strong interaction between the Cu species and the zeolite, which was similar to the reported results [27]. The acidity property is an essential part of the bifunctional catalyst. The acidity of catalyst was explored employing Py-IR and NH3-TPD, and the corresponding profiles are shown in Fig. 5b and c. The characteristic bands at 1543cm−1, 1490cm−1, and 1452cm−1 were found in the Cu/HZ40 and Cu@HZ40 samples, ascribed to B acid, L + B acid and Lewis (L) acid, respectively [40,41]. No characteristic band around 1543 cm−1 was observed in Cu@S-1 sample, indicating no B acidic sites. In Fig. 5b, the Cu/HZ40 and Cu@HZ40 showed three continuous ammonia desorption peaks in the range of 150-550 °C, indicating the presence of weak acid, medium acid, and strong acid [42]. The ammonia desorption area of Cu@S-1 implies that a small amount of weak acid mainly dominates the acidic properties. It has been reported that the strong acid of the zeolite is primarily derived from the B acid produced by the tetracoordinate Al of the zeolite framework. The center of the strong acid NH3 desorption peak of Cu/HZ40 and Cu@HZ40 is around 400°C, and the peak area is similar, demonstrating that both have identical B acid properties. These results reveal that the Al-rich catalyst prepared by the confinement method possesses rich B-acid properties similar to those of the Cu/HZ40 catalyst prepared by the impregnation method. 2.3 Catalysts performance for the FFA ring-opening to pentanediols The catalytic performance of zeolite-confined Cu NPs was investigated in the selective ring-opening hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol to pentanediol. For comparison, the reference catalyst was also evaluated under the same conditions. The results are shown in Fig. 6 a-d. Cu@HZ40 shows almost 100 % conversion of FFA with 92.1 % selectivity of PDO (76.4 % 1,5-PDO, 15.7 % 1,2-PDO) in 12 h time on stream (TOS). As a comparison catalyst, Cu/HZ40 achieved a similar FFA conversion within the first 4 hours of reaction, then a gradual decrease in the FFA conversion to 82.9% and a rapid decrease in the PDO selectivity from 88.1% initially to 36.3%, coupled with a gradual increase in the tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) selectivity from 5.0% to 44.4%. These results indicated that the reaction route of FFA hydrogenation to THFA was gradually enhanced as the reaction proceeded, and the reaction route of C-O bond cleavage of the furan ring was inhibited, which may be attributed to the metal-acid bifunctional imbalance caused by Cu NPS agglomeration and acidic carbon deposition in the Cu/HZ40 catalyst. In comparison, Cu@HZ40 prepared by the confined method has better activity and PDO selectivity in the reaction. Its stability was also significantly improved over that of Cu/HZ40 prepared by the impregnation method, which is attributed to its excellent metal sintering resistance and hierarchical pore structure. The unique encapsulation structure endows Cu NPS with higher stability, and the hierarchical pore structure facilitates the diffusion of intermediates and suppresses carbon deposition. The intimate proximity between the Cu NPS confined inside the zeolite and the Brønsted acid sites performed a better synergistic effect, further improving the catalytic activity and product selectivity of Cu@HZ40. The activity of the Cu@S-1 catalyst without tetracoordinated Al decreased rapidly in FFA conversion, and the selectivity of PDO decreased from 42.0% to 34.1%, showing a poor catalytic activity. This was because lacking B acid support limits the C-O cleavage in the furan ring, The confined metal nanoparticles promote the reaction pathway of furfuryl alcohol hydrogenation to THFA, showing high THFA selectivity. The catalytic performance of Cu@HZ40 at different temperatures (80-240 °C) and pressures (0.5-3.5 MPa) was also investigated. The results are shown in Fig. 6e and f. Cu@HZ40 showed a high FFA conversion in the range of 80-240°C, and the FFA conversion was up to 99 % after the reaction temperature exceeded 100°C, showing excellent catalytic activity. The PDO selectivity increased from 45.6% to 92.1% while THFA selectivity decreased from 47.6% to <1% when the reaction temperature was increased from 80°C to 160°C (Fig. S1). These results suggest that the increasing temperature favors the cleavage of the C-O bond in the furan ring and inhibits the reaction route of furfuryl alcohol hydrogenation to THFA. Interestingly, 1,5-PDO is the main product of PDO, and its selectivity is less affected by temperature (100-220°C). This indicates that the selective cleavage rate of the C2-O bond in the furan ring is much higher than that of the C5-O bond, and it is more prone to generate 1,5-PDO under the action of acid-metal bifunctional. Fig. 6f shows the effect of reaction pressure on selectivity and conversion. FFA was almost completely converted within 0.5-3.5MPa. With increasing pressure, the selectivity of PDO increases from 61.1% to 92.1%. It shows the best catalytic performance at 2.5 MPa, after which the selectivity decreases slightly and remains at 86.3% PDO selectivity, indicating that increasing the pressure within a specific range can promote the cleavage of the C-O bond of the furan ring. 2.4 Catalytic stability and reusability The bifunctional metal-B-acid catalyst often suffers from activity deactivation caused by carbon deposition and metal sintering. The XRD patterns of the spent catalyst were shown in Fig. S2. An obvious diffraction peak of Cu metal was observed in Cu / HZ40-spent, indicating that Cu metal particles appeared serious sintering phenomenon. A slight Cu diffraction peak was observed in Cu@HZ40-spent, and a small amount of metal agglomeration was observed in HAADF-STEM images of Cu@HZ40-spent with corresponding EDS mapping (Fig. S3), while most of them showed a uniform dispersion state, indicating that the metal exhibited excellent thermal stability after confined in HZ40. The stability and reusability of the catalyst are very significant for the industrial application. The stability of the Cu@HZ40 sample was evaluated at 95°C, 2.5 MPa, and WHSV = 0.19 h−1, and the result is shown in Fig. 7 a. The FFA conversion slightly decreased from 96.7% to 94.7% and the selectivity of PDO remained unchanged, showing excellent stability. The reusability of the Cu@HZ40 sample was tested at 160°C, 2.5 MPa and WHSV = 0.19 h−1, and the result is shown in Fig. 7b. The selectivity of THFA gradually increases while that of PDO gradually decreases. This may be caused by carbon deposition on B acidic sites, which weakens the ring-opening performance of FFA and strengthens the reaction pathway of FFA hydrogenation to THFA. This was fully confirmed by the TG/DTA result (Fig. S4). Even after two regenerations, the FFA conversion is still close to full conversion and the PDO selectivity reaches over 88%, showing superior reusability. 2.5 DFT calculation B acid sites are predominantly derived from the tetracoordinate alumina of zeolite. It has been shown to play a crucial synergistic role in converting of furfuryl alcohol to pentanediol [28,43]. The high activity of Cu@HZ40 has been further demonstrated using the DFT technique. The d-band of Cu in the catalyst was very close to the Fermi level (Fig. S5d, from − 1.688 eV to − 0.459 eV) after introducing tetracoordinated Al by the in-situ hydrothermal method, which caused a decrease in the surface energy and promoted the adsorption of FFA molecules. It has a lower surface energy than the impregnated Cu/HZ40. This was more conducive to the adsorption of reactant molecules. The differential charge density diagram is shown in Fig. 8 a, b, and c. Compared with Cu/HZ40 and Cu@S-1, Cu@HZ40 has an apparent electron transfer from Cu to HZ40, which improves the electron cloud density of the Al skeleton and is conducive to providing more electrons for participation in the ring-opening reaction. This was confirmed by the Bader charge (Fig. 8d, e, and f), and it was observed that the Cu Bader charges for Cu@HZ40 was significantly lower than that for Cu/HZ40 and Cu@S-1. To further verify the high activity of confined Al-rich Cu@HZ40 in the reaction, the elementary steps with energetic profiles for FFA ring opening on Cu@HZ40, Cu/HZ40, and Cu@S-1 were explored, respectively. The optimized structures of the intermediates and the transition states for the conversion of FFA to PDO on the three catalysts are shown in Figs. 9 , S6 and S7. According to the energy barriers of each step, it could be seen that the FFA ring-opening step (TS-1) was the controlling step of the reaction on all three catalysts. The ring-opening energy barrier of FFA at the C2-O cleavage was significantly lower than that at the C5-O cleavage. This is why PDO is dominated by 1,5-PDO in the product. By comparing the Cu@HZ40 and Cu@S-1 catalysts, the ring-opening energy barrier of FFA at the C2-O position on Cu@HZ40 was reduced from 2.27 eV to 1.84 eV after the introduction of tetracoordinate Al. This indicates that the introduction of tetracoordinate Al (B acidic site) reduces the ring-opening energy barrier of C2-O cleavage and improves the catalytic activity of Cu@HZ40. Simultaneously, the ring-opening energy barrier of Cu@HZ40 at the C2-O position of FFA is also lower than that of Cu/HZ40 prepared by impregnation (1.97 eV). This is because the unique preparation method obtains a close acid-metal distance and exhibits better activity in the reaction. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a Cu@HZ40 catalyst with Cu NPS confined in an Al-rich zeolite, which has uniformly dispersed small Cu nanoparticles and exhibits excellent anti-sintering performance in a high-temperature hydrogen environment. The successful introduction of tetracoordinated Al endows the catalyst with abundant B acid sites, achieving a complete FFA conversion and 92.1% PDO selectivity. DFT further proves that the unique metal-acid site structure after encapsulation significantly improves the ability to perform ring opening of furfuryl alcohol. Compared to metal/zeolite, the proximity of acid and metal sites in metal @ zeolite improves catalytic activity, which is more conducive to fully utilizing the metal-acid synergistic effect. This inspires the design and application of bifunctional anti-metal agglomeration catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional metal-acid catalysts have been widely used in the process of upgrading the molecules of biomass. As an important bifunctional catalyst, metal @ zeolite exhibits excellent sintering resistance and efficient catalytic performance, which is significant for improving practical applications. While the development of Al-rich zeolite-confined nanocluster catalysts is still a considerable challenge. In this paper, Cu@ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40) catalyst with Al-rich ZSM-5 zeolite-confined copper nanoclusters were designed and synthesized by the in-situ ligand-assisted hydrothermal crystallization method. The average size of the encapsulation metal clusters was only 2.3 nm after treatment at 400°C for 2 h in a hydrogen environment, which exhibits excellent thermal stability. 27Al MAS NMR and Pyridine-adsorbed IR (Py-IR) spectra confirmed that Al was successfully introduced into the zeolite framework. The intimate metal- Brønsted acidic site distribution enables complete conversion of furfuryl alcohol and 92.1 % selectivity of pentanediols. DFT calculations revealed that the high catalytic activity in catalyzing the ring opening of furfuryl alcohol to pentanediols could be attributed to the unique electronic effect in the Al-rich catalyst Cu@ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40). The in-situ ligand-assisted hydrothermal crystallization method will be very attractive regarding the simplicity required for industrial production. The Al-rich Cu@ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 40) catalyst was endowed with rich and dense metal-Brønsted acidic sites by a simple in-situ synthesis method, providing a practical and feasible path for the high-value utilization of biomass molecules.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ hydrothermal synthesis of Al-rich Cu@ZSM-5 catalyst for furfuryl alcohol upgrading to pentanediols
